Torulaspora globosa is a species of yeast that belongs to the genus Torulaspora. It is a unicellular eukaryotic microorganism that reproduces asexually through budding. The cells of T. globosa are typically spherical or globose in shape, with a smooth cell surface and a diameter ranging from 3 to 5 micrometers.

T. globosa is known to be involved in various fermentation processes, particularly in the production of alcoholic beverages, such as wine and beer. Its ability to ferment sugars and produce ethanol makes it a valuable microorganism in the food and beverage industries.

This yeast species is commonly found in environments associated with fermentation, such as grape must, fruit juices, and brewery environments. It is also known to be present in the gastrointestinal tract of various animals, including humans, where it may contribute to the overall microbial community.

Genetically, T. globosa is characterized by a haploid genome and can undergo meiosis to produce ascospores, which are resistant structures that allow the yeast to survive unfavorable environmental conditions. The study of T. globosa and its genetic and physiological properties can provide insights into the diversity and role of yeasts in various natural and industrial processes.
